phases.title: Fundamentals
phases.summary: This part of the module covers all of the essential concepts, tools and techniques that you'll need to be build habitable software in Ruby.

topics.title: Ruby
topics.summary: An introduction to Ruby, which is the - purely object-oriented and somewhat functional - programming language used in DAMS.

videos.title: Ruby
videos.description: Briefly introduces Ruby, comparing it to Java and Python.

videos.title: Ruby Gems
videos.description: Introduces RubyGems and Bundler for managing Ruby dependencies.

topics.title: Approach
topics.summary: A very light introduction to software engineering processes, and a look at some of the challenges you might face when using a reactive (Agile) approach.

videos.title: Planning vs. reacting
videos.description: An argument for combining plan-driven and reactionary software engineering.

videos.title: TDD and RSpec
videos.description: A recap of TDD and an overview of the RSpec testing framework.

videos.title: Test doubles
videos.description: A set of techniques that can be used bring almost any code under test.

topics.title: Tools
topics.summary: A brief introduction to three of the key tools used in DAMS.

videos.title: Ruby Parser
videos.description: An overview of the fundamentals of program analysis in Ruby.

videos.title: Vagrant
videos.description: A solution to the "It works on my machine" problem.

videos.title: Git
videos.description: A recap of version control, and a brief introduction to Git.

phases.title: Habitable Programs
phases.summary: This is the core of the module. You'll learn about seven factors that increase the habitability of software, often by taking appropriate measurements and applying suitable refactorings.

topics.title: Leaner
topics.summary: Lean software has no extra parts. Every part is factored into small pieces.

videos.title: Why lean?
videos.description: Lean software solves a single problem well.

videos.title: Size metrics
videos.description: The Lines of Code metric, and alternatives to it.

videos.title: Getting lean
videos.description: The Extract Method and Extract Class refactorings.

topics.title: Less Complex
topics.summary: Methods that have fewer control-flow paths are easier to reason about, and hence easier to maintain.

videos.title: Why simplicity?
videos.description: An exploration of complexity in software, and how simplicity can win.

videos.title: Complexity metrics
videos.description: The McCabe Cyclomatic and ABC metrics for quantifying complexity.

videos.title: Getting simple
videos.description: Tactics for avoiding loops and conditionals.

topics.title: Loose Coupling
topics.summary: Loosely coupled software can be altered without affecting its collaborators, and re-used in new contexts.

videos.title: Why loose coupling?
videos.description: Explains how dependencies are powerful yet perilious.

videos.title: Coupling metrics
videos.description: The MPC and CBO metrics for quantifying coupling.

videos.title: Getting loose coupling
videos.description: Dependency injection, inversion of control, tell don't ask and gateways.

topics.title: More Cohesive
topics.summary: When software is arranged such that similar parts are close to each other, it is easier to maintain because changes are localised.

videos.title: Why cohesion?
videos.description: Some parts of our software simply belong together.

videos.title: Cohesion metrics
videos.description: The LCOM4 cohesion metric for identifying classes with many responsibilities.

videos.title: Getting cohesion
videos.description: Extacting classes, moving methods, and using wrappers.

topics.title: Avoiding Duplication
topics.summary: In software where every piece of knowledge is specified once and only once, changes become easier to make as they are often contained in a single location.

videos.title: Why not duplicate?
videos.description: Avoiding duplication of knowledge is key to habitable software.

videos.title: Clone detection
videos.description: Baker's algorithm for detecting similar fragments of code.

videos.title: Reducing duplication
videos.description: Making clones more alike, template methods, and strategies.

topics.title: Clarity
topics.summary: Code is read much more often than it is written. Therefore, habitable software reads like a good story well told.

videos.title: Why clarity?
videos.description: Clarity is crucial because code is read more often than it is written.

videos.title: Clear names
videos.description: Naming is one of the hardest problems in computer science.

videos.title: Clear documentation
videos.description: Bad documentation can seed doubt, confusion and despair!

videos.title: Clear narratives
videos.description: Habitable software reads like a good story well told.

topics.title: Extensibility
topics.summary: Extensible software allows its core functionality to be enriched at runtime without altering its code.

videos.title: Why extensibility?
videos.description: Enhancing a system's functionality without re-opening components.

videos.title: Observers
videos.description: Decoupling components by using observers to communicate events.

videos.title: Middleware
videos.description: Decomposing message-processing applications with middleware.

videos.title: Plug-ins
videos.description: How to implement a plug-in architecture with Ruby modules.

phases.title: Habitable Systems
phases.summary: This is the bonus material for the module: it covers some recent trends in software engineering that can be applied to increase habitability. (Coming soon...)
